bibl.title: Letter from Mrs. George Carroll to Philip Showalter Hench, February 4, 1954

div1.p: Mrs. Carroll informs Hench that she is unable to go through the records of James Carroll. She will be unavailable to meet with Hench the next time he is in Washington, D.C.

div1.head: Letter from Mrs. George Carroll to Philip Showalter Hench, February 4, 1954
div1.opener:
February 4, 1954.
Dr. P. S. Hench,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minnesota.
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I regret to inform you that I will not be mentally or physically
able to go through the records of my husband's father, Dr. James
Carroll when you come to Washington this month.

Time, which is said to be a great healer has done nothing for me
so far. I am worse now than when my husband passed away for the
loneliness is almost more than I can endure. I am not socially
inclined and go very little and I think my relatives are a little
weary of hearing me talk about my loss. Most people are too
wrapped up in their own affairs to bother much about the woes of
others, so I have become discouraged, despondent and have lost the
will to live. I keep to myself as much as possible and watch TV.

I have not yet located the keys to open the trunks. For some
reason or other, I never bothered to ask my husband which keys were
which. He has a number of them among his possessions and some
day, maybe months from now, I will be able to go through the things
without going all to pieces. Just now, I am too emotionally unstable
and another thing the basement is so cold that I cannot spend much
time there as I am having a flare-up of arthritis and try to spend
my time in a warm place.

I have not made any decision about the operation on my feet but
they are very sore and deformed. Dr. Gibson suggested the operation
but my family Dr. says at my age to let well enough alone. He thinks
that if I have gotten along so far, it is too late in life to take the
risk. So you see when one gets conflicting opinions it is difficult
to make a decision. I have stopped all treatments for the time being
for I am too despondent to care what happens to me.

Some day I may have a different out-look on life but until then,
I will not be able to help you with the records. I do not think I
will be here the week of February 17 as I may go to Pennsylvania for
a couple of weeks in an effort to forget my troubles.

closer.signed:
Mrs. George S. H. Carroll,
2814 Rhode Island Avenue, N. E.,
Washington 18, D. C.
